sn45.1:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn45.1:4.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn45.1:5.1: “Mendicants, ignorance precedes the attainment of unwholesome qualities, with lack of conscience and prudence following along.
sn45.1:5.2: An ignoramus, sunk in ignorance, gives rise to wrong view.
sn45.1:5.3: Wrong view gives rise to wrong motivation.
sn45.1:5.4: Wrong motivation gives rise to wrong speech.
sn45.1:5.5: Wrong speech gives rise to wrong action.
sn45.1:5.6: Wrong action gives rise to wrong livelihood.
sn45.1:5.7: Wrong livelihood gives rise to wrong effort.
sn45.1:5.8: Wrong effort gives rise to wrong mindfulness.
sn45.1:5.9: Wrong mindfulness gives rise to wrong samādhi.
sn45.1:6.1: Knowledge precedes the attainment of wholesome qualities, with conscience and prudence following along.
sn45.1:6.2: A sage, firm in knowledge, gives rise to right view.
sn45.1:6.3: Right view gives rise to right motivation.
sn45.1:6.4: Right motivation gives rise to right speech.
sn45.1:6.5: Right speech gives rise to right action.
sn45.1:6.6: Right action gives rise to right livelihood.
sn45.1:6.7: Right livelihood gives rise to right effort.
sn45.1:6.8: Right effort gives rise to right mindfulness.
sn45.1:6.9: Right mindfulness gives rise to right samādhi.”
